segments.text: Welcome to Rising. We have a stellar show planned for you this Wednesday morning. I was a little late because I had difficulty finding an electronic scooter that was working.
I didn't want to block two blocks until I got one. Then I was hitting every light. I loved to just zip through traffic. I was being especially against taking risks this morning.
Well, I'm glad that you are risk averse. I hope one day that gets you to wear a helmet on your way to work.
I thought this was still a free country, but maybe not.

Let's get to the news. First up, a settlement has been reached. In one of the most historic defamation cases in American history, Dominion Voting Systems versus Fox News, just moments before opening statements were set to begin Tuesday afternoon.
Fox News agreed to pay nearly $800 million to Dominion over promoting falsehoods that the 2020 election was rigged and that Dominion's machines counted fraudulent votes.

The settlement shields Fox from what was likely to have been grueling and potentially embarrassing coverage of internal strife between the network's executives, anchors and producers in the weeks leading to the 2020 election.
Lead Dominion attorney Justin Nelson spoke outside the courthouse yesterday. Let's watch.

The truth matters. Lies have consequences. Over two years ago, a torrent of lies swept Dominion and election officials across America into an alternative universe of conspiracy theories caused by the United States.
Causing grievous harm to Dominion and the country. Today's settlement of $787,500,000 represents vindication and accountability. Lies have consequences.

Fox News is not completely out of the woods yet. The media giant is facing another multi-billion dollar lawsuit from another voting technology company Smartmatic that alleges Fox broadcast lies that decimated its business.
So there will be another one of these suits potentially could be a settlement as well. Maybe earlier this time.
I think it's obvious that Dominion was in a really strong position despite the very high bar that a defamation lawsuit like this has to clear.
There were setbacks for Fox even as recently as last week in terms of they had put off the judge with some of the attorney's behavior and not disclosing exactly what what the attorney's actions were.
What Rupert Murdoch's title and position was. So the jury was delayed while they could really see if they could put together a last minute deal.

It's funny. I was just watching. I've been rewatching succession with my wife who's watching it for the first time and we just watched the episode at like the shareholders meeting where they're rushing to make a deal with the coalition of people who are trying to take over the business.
And I was watching this as this was happening. It was felt very similar echoes like last minute. Can they deal together?
That's not wrong. Look, I in my experience, you know, as an attorney cases settle. Case of settle because litigation is incredibly expensive.
And takes forever. And takes forever. And it's frankly unpredictable and these corporations are risk averse.

And look, I know that some people feel as though Dominion should have pushed through one because of the kind of public disclosure value of unpacking more of what's been going on behind the scenes at Fox.
Others feel as though the settlement value of $700 million or so much less than the $1.6 billion.
But keep in mind, $700 and nearly $8 million is many times.
Yeah, is many is many times more than Dominion's yearly earnings, like by orders of magnitude.
This is a real boon for that company. Also, it's worth noting kind of the posture you referenced some of the antagonism that had happened with some of the lawyers and the judge.
But there's a lot of others that went down this week. The judge sanctioned Fox News for withholding evidence, admonished it for not being straightforward with him.
He said he would allow Dominion to conduct an additional deposition with Rupert Murdoch at Fox's expense.

And I think that that from a Fox News perspective, having that deposition, knowing what we've gotten out so far, the potential embarrassment of that hanging over their head might have been one of the things that went ahead and pushed them over into settlement territory.
And the judge also had ruled that Fox lawyers could not use newsworthiness as a legal defense, which narrowed their potential trial strategies.
So the idea that even if something was wrong, it's something that people are saying, so we should have people long to cover it.
Once that's off the table, it's not really clear what they really would have in terms of counter-arguments here.
Well, and look, I think you could argue that this is a good outcome.
Right, I know many people, many critics of Fox were eager to learn even more damaging and embarrassing information about the company.
That was the major animating agenda of so many mainstream media outlets covering this gleefully.
And you know what, turn about is fair play.
Fox would cover their legal troubles with great glee as well.
So, you know, these are rival firms within an industry battling each other fine.
You know, that's the way it is.
But I think, and I've said, as when we've discussed this, that I would be concerned from a journalistic standpoint,
from a freedom of expression standpoint, about a ruling on the books that impacts a media company's ability to have on guests,
even guests that are cranks and have controversial, likely wrong things to say,
because sometimes a perspective that seems laughable and wrong and is totally counter to everything legitimate people think,
and is totally conspiratorial, every now and then it ends up to be right.
We at our show, we explore some of those things along the lines of at least foreign policy,
and perhaps COVID, some things that were utterly preposterous have are not so preposterous anymore.
So, I would worry about a slippery slope along that line if there was a ruling on the books saying that they were ultimately
guilty of defamation.
We didn't cross that bridge. They paid, so they have to make right to this company that was harmed by the statements made by guests on the program.
So, maybe this is a win-win-win situation.
It is worth noting that this is a defamation claim, and the idea that there might be a guest who is incorrect.
So, there's two layers of this.
One, it's knowing that the guest is going to say something incorrect, factually incorrect, not opinion-based incorrect,
but factually incorrect and having it on anyway, despite there being, again, a record of internal conversation that acknowledges that the only value of having this person on,
is that it appeals to an audience that is very pro-Trump and is embracing this argument not for fact reasons,
but because it bolsters a narrative from a politician that they enjoy and will help thoughts on the ratings.
So, that's one aspect of it.
The other aspect of it is the defamation aspect.
So, conceivably, you could have all those other elements, a guest that you know is incorrect, that you have on anyway because the audience likes it,
but the guest, what they're saying, doesn't defame another party.
So, the slippery slope argument would require a lot of different parts of this to be in place.
The idea that we have a guest on that says, I don't know, you know, aliens have landed in, invaded Joe Biden's brain, you know, a guest defamed Joe Biden,
but let's say, aliens have-
Well, a public figure is harder.
Sure.
So, aliens have invaded in there, you know, all over New Jersey.
Okay.
You know, you can have that on, but you're still not in the context where you're in this position,
where you're being sued for defamation because conceivably, who was actually hurt, it's a weird story, it's a wrong story,
and I undermine the credibility of the institution.
So, I hear what you're saying about that, but I do think it's worth parsing out exactly what would be required,
not just the defamation, but also, a-
an express behind the scenes knowledge based on documents that we have written or communications that have otherwise been captured between us,
that admit that we know better and are only doing something to advance the financial interest of the company,
which, again, is not something that I think that is journalism or I'm especially concerned about protecting.
Yeah, I think it is-
it should be perfectly open to criticism, but again, this was a lawsuit,
and a lawsuit aimed not just at the people who literally made the statements, but a lawsuit aimed at the platform at which the statements were made,
and yes, we're learning some pretty damning and embarrassing things about what some of the figures involved who decided to platform those people really, really thought about them,
but I would- and I would say they should take their licks from now that's in the public record,
and you should, you know, think whatever you think about those people or their integrity based on that,
but again, a decision on the books that then impacts the financial bottom line of a company and might make other media companies very wary to have-
to have weirdos and outsiders be a part of the dialogue doesn't seem like something to me that necessarily serves the public interest.
Well, what do you make about this argument that some folks are making that the settlement doesn't include an apology?
That Dominion- that Fox News doesn't actually have to admit that it spread misinformation and that it was wrong.
You saw a little bit in the Dominion representatives, a spokesperson there that said that the settlement is accountability, that's the line they've been using,
that the settlement is accountability, that apologies are about accountability, and since we're having the settlement, that's efficient.
What do you make of that?
So Fox News said in a statement about the settlement, we acknowledge the court's rulings finding certain claims about Dominion to be false.
This settlement reflects Fox's continued commitment to the highest journalistic standards, so they acknowledge that the claims made were false.
You're right, it's not a- it's- they don't technically say the words we are sorry or we apologize.
They are paying, you know, three quarters of billion dollars.
And again, it's not just that there was some false claims. Sometimes false claims get made on the air.
The question is whether or not they knowingly created a context for false claims to be said.
Knowingly said, we know this is malarkey, but we're going to have these guests on because we know our audience likes malarkey and we're going to feed it to them.
That's the bit that gets the company on the hook as opposed to the individuals, and that's the bit for which I think some people are still wanting an apology.

But look, there's this other lawsuit coming down the pike and we'll see if those, as you say, are kind of thirsty for it or rabid for it among a larger liberal audience will actually get what they're looking for.
More rising right after this.

Alabama police have arrested two people in connection with a birthday party shooting.
They killed four people and wounded 32 over the weekend.
Tyrik McCullough, 17 years old, and Travis McCullough, 16 years old, have been charged with four counts of reckless murder.
Police have identified the victims as 23 year old Corbin de Monterey Holston, 19 year old Marcia and Manuel Collins, 18 year old Philstavius Daudel, and 17 year old Sean Kiva, Kiki, Nicole Smith.
They were shot and killed while attending a sweet 16 birthday party shortly after 10 30 p.m. on Saturday night.
Here's Alabama police speaking on the matter.

On Tuesday, April 18 at approximately 8 p.m. Alabama law enforcement agencies state and road investigation officially arrested and charged Tyrik McCullough, 17 of Tuskegee and Travis McCullough, 16, also of Tuskegee with four counts of reckless murder each.
So they did not specify a potential motive for the shooting yet.
I take it from reading the coverage that these the shooters were at the event.
It's difficult.
It's hard to tell.
It's a little odd.
I know this is just breaking.
And so we don't.
I mean it's breaking that they were arrested.
Obviously this did happen over the weekend.
So I know I know that it's just breaking.

So there's a reason why perhaps we don't have those details, but if they were at the event, it seems like that should be an obvious like a very easy thing to figure out. But as for some background that it was one of the deceased sisters, sweet 16 Alexis Daudel.
And she said she was looking forward to this.
She had butterflies in her stomach.
There was a rumor at the party that someone had a gun at which point.
Their mother made an announcement over the speaker saying if anyone here has a gun, you need to leave.
We're here to celebrate a sweet 16 party.
And they tried to figure out who it was.
They did it and the party kept going.
And then all of a sudden while people were dancing on the dance floor, they heard gunfire and Alexis says, all I remember is my brother grabbing me and pushing me down to the ground.
She fell into a pool of blood.
She sat up and ran outside.
Afterward, she reunited with her mom, but she couldn't find her brother.
And when the shooting stopped, they saw him and a lot of others obviously on the dance floor and blood.
I mean, it sounds like an absolutely horrific, horrific event.
So I'm very eager to find out what the possible motive could be, why people at the party would start shooting in this way, shooting people that they know.
And if it's not someone at the party, what their motives could have been to do something as horrific as this.
Right, these individuals in custody are being charged as adults.
They're 16 and 17.
So they'll be much deeper potential penalties there.
You know, it's interesting how these things take shape in the public perception.
There's not been protests about this or even calls for gun control protests or protests about crime.
This is a mass shooting.
A number of people, four people dead, many other shot.
That satisfies the criteria of a mass shooting.
But it's not, I don't know that it's being characterized or discussed in the same way.
The school shootings we've talked about or the bank shooting from the other week are described.
It's, you see what I'm getting at?
I don't know.
I mean, I just, I don't know much about this case.
I don't know much about whether there have been protests.
I mean, there are a lot of-
There's not been as much news coverage on it.
For example, there wasn't a protest over the woman who was killed turning around in the driveway as far as I know.
The protest around the first case with the 16-year-old who rang the doorbell and was shot was over whether or not the guy was going to be charged.
There seemed to be some delay in charging and arresting the person who did the shooting.
I think there was some concern because there have been a pattern of other cases where folks have not been charged.
Remember, there was a DC case where the kid who was perceived to be at least trying to steal a car was shot by a homeowner outside of the house and wasn't charged for quite some time.
So I think that the protest tend to be not that something happened, but that there has been a failure in the justice system and actually pursuing the case.
And this one, it looks like they obviously, they caught people who really suspect and are likely to charge them or charge them as adults.
Ultimately, there hasn't been a failure in the justice system with respect to the teenage boy shot the doorbell shooting so far.
Well now, the protests happened because the guy wasn't charged.
Those happened immediately in that gap period.
I don't know if there have been subsequent protests, but absolutely I think that there should be an attention to gun laws in this case.
Absolutely. Alabama has one of the highest.
We talked about this yesterday.

How when we're talking about dangerous cities and dangerous states, there was this weird politicization where conservatives tend to want to say Democrats are hypocrites for having, you know, cities, urban cities with crime, when so many of the states and localities with the highest amount of gun violence
are in fact, and not that this should be about this, but in conservative states like Alabama and Alabama and cities in Alabama often rank very highly on that list.

That's another reason I suspect the attention, not as much paid to this was, these were, these were not, you know, AR-15s, the guns that are, as I've said on this show, as most gun crimes are, most violent crimes, most murders are committed by the much more common kind of gun, the handguns,
not the really destructive weapons that everyone gets so incensed about that are responsible for a tiny fraction.
And the story has been covered broadly. I'm looking at a Vox piece, Buzzfeed News, etc.
It's worth noting and people have been talking about this gun violence in the context of this case, noting that gun violence is the leading cause of death among Alabama children.
I think what's interesting is that some people who are perhaps more right-leaning will often say things like, well, that statistic doesn't really matter.
It's not a real statistic because it is cases like this or cases that are perceived to be about internal disputes, gang violence, and that that is not what some folks are really concerned about.

I think a lot of members in living communities, where they're subject to this kind of violence, are very much concerned about the proliferation of guns, and they're very much, I think, victimized by how easy it is to get a gun, particularly in red states.
But if anyone's saying it doesn't matter because of the particulars, that would be a bad thing to say.
I guess what I'll suggest is that there's a specific, when there is a racism component to it, it can get a crime, can get a, I mean, this is what we've seen happen.
It gets a national discussion and hearing that equally horrific or even crimes involving even more deaths don't get if there's not the racism component.
Yeah, there's a lot of things that can escalate a crime to a national prominence.

Often, there's been very much studied how if the victim of a crime, a murder, is white, blonde woman, they get a lot more coverage even the most missing children in the United States are not white, blonde women.

So there's a lot of ways in which bias or a sense of salaciousness or what the public appetite is for drives news coverage, and sometimes that means that black victims of crime are ignored in favor of white victims of crime symptoms.
Sometimes it means that white perpetrators of crimes that be focused on more than others, and I think it's worth having a robust conversation about why that is for sure.
Well, we'll have more rising right after this.

Another very tragic story to discuss having to do with the Stand Your Ground debate, this time out of Texas, two cheerleaders were shot yesterday after one apparently got into the wrong car in a supermarket parking lot,
going to Heather Roth, her and three of her teammates carpooled to a local HEB grocery store after practice where some girls had parked their cars.
Heather exited the car and opened the door to a different parked vehicle thinking it was hers, something many of us have done.
When she noticed a man sitting in the passenger seat, she closed the car door and re-entered the carpool vehicle.
Now, that man has been identified as 25-year-old Telo Rodriguez Jr.
He got out of his car to confront the girls.
Now, Heather says that as she rolled down her window to apologize for the misunderstanding, he began shooting, striking two of the cheerleaders.
One victim was treated and released at the scene, another identified by family's 18-year-old, Peyton Washington, currently in the ICU in critical condition.
Rodriguez has been arrested and charged with deadly conduct, a third-degree felony in Texas.
So, this is horrible. So, Roth was grazed by a bullet, Washington, who's still in the ICU, was shot in the leg in the back.
Apparently, Washington was a real superstar in the cheerleading world and is known to people who are competitive and in the know about that particular athletic field as a real star.
This is an incredible tragedy and it is compounded by the fact that this is now the third story that we've talked about this week,
where someone making an honest mistake, knocking on the door, ringing the doorbell of the wrong house, turning around in a stranger's driveway,
and now getting in the wrong car. So, I mean, that in the error of Ubers and lifts, we've all done.
I literally put my hand on the handle of the wrong car this morning before getting in the right car on the way to work,
or find themselves gunned down. Now, this situation is a little bit different.
There was even more of a feeling of premeditation in this one, given that they tried to get into the car.
They got back into the air, and at that point, yes, he gets out, comes over, they rolled down their window to apologize,
never anticipating it in a million years, I'm sure that they were about to be shot at, and then this happened.
So, there are, of course, we're comparing it to similar-ish seeming incidents with the car that pulled into the wrong driveway,
turned around, and a woman shot and killed there. And then, of course, this case of the boy,
Ralph Yarl, who was shot after ringing the wrong doorbell by the man in the house shot and killed him,
shot him in the head, he's been released doing a lot better, thankfully.
Now, in both of those cases, the alleged perpetrator was an older man, a 65-year-old man, an 85-year-old man.
This was a 25-year-old seemingly Hispanic man, also, you know, race in the case of Yarl is being discussed,
because he's black, the shooter was white, there's been some protests, some people calling for there to be racial motivation.
I think even one of the law enforcement authorities has suggested they have some evidence that there might be a racist motivation.
But in the second case, it seems like everybody involved was white.
Right. And that case- We don't know a lot about losses in the car, but at least the woman who was killed was white.
Yeah, and in this case, you don't have a, you have a, I guess we don't know the racial makeup of the cheerleader.
Precisely, the perpetrator seems to be a Hispanic man and much younger, not an older fellow.
So, I don't know. Again, I say what I said about those cases, there is no right, regardless of any stand or ground law.
To that effect, there is no right to just shoot someone after they-
Yeah, another-
You stand your car for another car.
Another difference is that, you know, forced-stand-the-ground law to go into effect.
Generally speaking, to have a self-defense claim, you have to be able to show that the deadly force was necessary to protect yourself, right?

And the exception is defending your castle, which is why people are perhaps increasingly emboldened to shoot from their porches, the way that happened in the first two cases, feeling like they have some protection or some entitlement to do whatever it takes to defend their property.
And also, civilly, you don't have to- So defend, right, so the standard ground removes- Without standard ground, there's a duty to retreat if retreat is an option.
Like, you can still defend yourself if there's no standard ground law. It's just your first, your support, your duty to retreat.
Right.
So, Andrew Ground says, if they're coming at you, you don't have to make the decision to retreat, you can fire.
But that doesn't apply here, because he affirmatively- He didn't shoot her when she tried to get into the wrong car door.
He got out of his car, went to their car, and shot.
So, that's not even bringing in a duty to retreat.
You don't have a duty to retreat, you can stand your ground, because he then affirmatively went and made the shot.
So, that's not going to- So, there's not going to be a protection you can turn to in there.

And to be clear, originally, the castle doctrine applied to your house, and the whole point of standing there ground was expanding that castle doctrine to everywhere you are in the state, so that you never have the duty to retreat.
This is- That is why this case, it feels like an escalation. It feels like-
So, I mean, not that this person had knowledge of the other cases, and it's a literal escalation, but-
As we covered- In the first case, it was completely, it seems, unjustified, but happened at someone's doorstep.
In the second place, it's someone coming out of their house and shooting folks turning around in their driveway.
Nowhere near them, it's hard to make- See what kind of case you can make at all for their being, even a subjective feeling of fear.
And now, in this case, two cheerleaders walking away from your car, getting in their own car, prepared to drive away, and to go walk up to them and shoot them,

It's really- It's really unconscionable. And it really does raise the question, whether the unconscionability of it will cause anybody to have more robust conversations about how to actually prevent these things from happening,

or if we accept that we just live in a world where the second amendment means that sometimes people who are maybe crazy or potentially racist or just evil are going to have the ability to so easily jeopardize the situation.
And that's why we jeopardize the lives of others.
Sure, and look, I should say that even though we're talking about three similar cases here, these are getting media attention, and so we're talking about them as part of the media.
We don't- Just because we've seen three cases, it does not mean necessarily that this is becoming more common or was even more common like this week.
Just because these things are getting more media attention, we'd have to do a rigorous- We'd have to look at the statistics.

So, you know, if this is actually increasing, it may not be increasing, it may be coincidence, it may be- It may be that three of these kinds of incidents happen every week, and just that first one got some media attention for whatever reason,
so now people look on the lookout for others, we don't know. That could be the case.
Yeah, it's interesting. I saw- There was some reporting, I believe, in the post about the shooter in the first case with Ralph Yarl having a no-solicitation sign on him.

And the implication was that somehow that justified the shooter's behavior that Ralph Yarl, who again thought he was at the right address, somewhere where he was supposed to be to pick up his siblings, you know, should have known better than to knock on that door.
You can in fact still solicit a house that has a no-solicitation sign.

I know that from my brief, brief career, one of the only like real jobs I had before I started doing journalism, I did door knocking for Comcast in one summer in college, and one of the first things they told us is you can still knock the door.
There's just no-solicitation sign, that's not like legally enforceable at all.

Yeah, so I mean, I bring it up to say that despite what feels like a very clear-cut situation, a 16-year-old boy picking up his siblings, being gunned down by a guy through glass, you know, there was a barrier between them.
There's no words were said between the two, you know, there's still this effort to come up with subjective reasons why a person could be justified in shooting.

And I think that really gets to the heart of this where, standard ground laws, qualified immunity, which is what we're talking about in the context of police using disproportionate force, it always comes down to whether a jury, whether the public, believes in a sense of somebody's subjective sense of danger.

And when I read the no-solicitation story, it's clear to me that to a lot of people, a young, like a kid, a 16-year-old, especially a black kid, you heard the shooter in that case say that the size of the kid made him afraid.
I mean, he looks 16-year-old size to me, and I know there's obviously a range of sizes, but he wasn't some 6'5", you know, super advanced looking kid.
The size of the cheerleaders was intimidating.
Exactly.
So, you know, given the size of the woman pulling away in her car.
That's what's so frustrating.

But it seems like, from my subjective belief, I would have imagined that anyone would be trying to make excuses around that first case, and yet we see it happening, which is why I really am skeptical that this will lead to a more robust interrogation of the value of the standard ground law, which puts us in the position of having to make those kind of subjective
judgments, instead of being in a different kind of realm where the onus is on the person with the gun to have the obligation not to shoot unless their lives are actually imperiled.
Yeah, well, sure.

I mean, if these people were operating off of a wrongful impression of the law that it allows them, again, to just kill on-site someone who rings the wrong doorbell or turns around in their driveway, or I think even more unlikely in the third case, you know, tries to get into the wrong...
...the cheerleader tries to get into the wrong door, then that will be something to reflect upon.
But it does not give them that power.
It is a power to defend yourself when that is necessary rather than just running away and fleeing.
Or being in a dangerous situation.
Sometimes people try to rob convenience stores or rob a dining establishment.
There are, if there is a standard ground thing, in effect, you can fight back.
You can not consent to have your property taken or anything like that.
And I support that.
This is so clearly not that.
And people should not treat it as, again, an invitation to go around shooting people for no reason.
People who do that should be brought to justice in all contexts.
Well, we know more about this story and more about the perpetrator in this case.
We will bring that news to you here on Rising.
More Rising after this.
Twitter has removed its policy against the, quote, targeted misgendering or deadmaiming of transgender individuals, AP reports.
Back in 2018, Twitter enacted the policy against deadmaiming, which is referring to a transgender person by their pre-transition name,
as well as, quote, purposefully using the wrong gender for someone as a form of harassment.
On Monday, Twitter said it would only put warning labels on some tweets that are, quote, potentially in violation of its rules against hateful conduct.

President and CEO of the advocacy group GLAD, Sarah Kate Ellis, said, Twitter's decision to convertly roll back its longtime policy is the latest example of just how unsafe the company is for users and advertisers alike.
Yeah, this was a tough one.

So, first it should be noted that, you know, just in the interview he did with Tucker Carlson, Tucker Carlson asked him a question about how he was able to get rid of 80% of the workforce and still have the site function.
And Elon specifically said, well, if you're not trying to one run a kind of a nonprofit charity, but also if you're not doing as much content moderation, he referred to a censorship.
I don't mean to make a value judgment there, but if you're not doing as much censorship, then you don't need as much staff.

This kind of a decision does seem to be aligned with the idea that you simply can't police as much as the internet and make these kind of discrete content moderation decisions if you made a commitment to really parrying down your staff.
So here we are.
Substantively-
What is that a bad thing?

Yeah, substantively, it does feel like this one, many of the content moderation decisions that relied on more subjective assessments of what is harassment always felt a little difficult to police just because they were so subjected.
So there were people who were asking, well, if I make reference to something that Caitlyn Jenner did, like winning the decathlon back when she identified as Bruce Jenner, is that dead naming?
Did those sentence that I just say qualify as dead naming?
Right.
And I don't know that content moderators really should be in that position, even though I have a personal belief against dead naming or misgendering people.
I just pulled up Wikipedia for Caitlyn Jenner.
It lists Caitlyn Jenner's birth name as William Bruce Jenner.
This is a famous person who was known to millions of people as Bruce Jenner before they transitioned, and now she's Caitlyn Jenner.

And I don't, yeah, I don't understand, for like historical purposes, for almost journalistic purposes, the kind of dead naming prohibition, especially for people who are already known as the other name seems not well thought out to me.

Or at least no one's explained why this is such a stark example of harassment that this cannot be tolerated, that this is worse than, I mean, I'm sure people make nasty comments to you online all the time.
They make nasty comments.
Every day, I am caught a genocide denier and my face is plastered all over the picture of dead children.
There's no specific policy of banning every account that does that to you.
If somebody spams you with that, maybe they should get banned.
And if someone spanned Caitlyn Jenner with, then maybe they should get banned.
But just having a policy of just mentioning that and banning that person seems much more ideological to me.
Yeah, it is interesting.
That's a good point.
I have been photoshopped onto cotton fields.
I have been subjected to all kinds of racist remarks and photoshops.
I had someone once taken a video, a real video of me saying something for the Bernie campaign and then putting subtitles on it that made it look like I was saying something else entirely.
This is before AI.
That I would report.
And I reported all of those things and nothing has ever happened.
Nothing has ever happened.
And I'm not even necessarily complaining about that, but it is, I think a lot of people react to, including some trans activists, is that what gets taken down is very inconsistent.
And the realm of Elon.
And if you don't want to see that, you can always block this person and then you can't see them doing this.
You have Twitter and other social media sites empower you to make moderation decisions on behalf of what you yourself consume.

Rather than having one rule that we must all abide by that obviously can't be enforced with any sort of rigor and fairness, the better thing is to empower individual users to have more tools and choices to see what kind of things they can see.
